SPRINGFIELD - The two men had already pocketed $600 in cash from an armed robbery at a Springfield couple's apartment Friday afternoon, a prosecutor said. But before leaving, one suspect pointed a gun at the young mother and threatened to shoot her, Assistant District Attorney Thomas Prendergast told a judge Monday in Springfield District Court. Then he tried to "pull the earrings out of her ear even as she was holding her three-year-old child," the prosecutor added. Springfield police arrested Victor Awosika, 33, of Springfield, a few miles away, with cash, clothing and other items stolen from the home on Cedar Street, Prendergast said. A second suspect remains at large. Held over the weekend, Awosika pleaded not guilty Monday in Springfield District Court to ten charges, including four counts of home invasion and two counts of armed robbery. Minutes after the men fled the apartment, police began searching for a black Chrysler 300 with New Jersey plates, based on descriptions from the victims and a neighbor, the prosecutor said. When police pulled the Chrysler over near Interstate 291, Awosika was alone; both victims later identified him as the gunman, but said he was wearing a different shirt during the robbery, Prendergast said. The prosecutor asked Judge William Hadley to set bail at $50,000, citing the new charges and Awosika's 10-page criminal record. In addition convictions for distributing crack cocaine and other charges, Awosika is currently out on bail in a 2017 case, and on probation in a 2016 case, Prendergast said. Victor Awosika of Springfield pleads guilty to distributing crack cocaine, related charges The defendant, who faces up to 40 years in prison, will be sentenced on Sept. 30. He called for the judge to revoke the defendant's bail, effectively jailing him for 90 days. State probation officer Ramon Guzman, citing the new charges, also requested that Awosika be detained for a probation violation hearing in the 2016 case. Awosika has been on probation in four cases, and violated his probation in three of them, Guzman said. Defense lawyer Ivonne Vidal asked for $5,000 bail, and opposed revoking her client's release in the earlier cases. The two suspects in the alleged home invasion were described as black males in their 20s, both wearing black hoodies, with one being taller and skinnier than the other, Vidal said. Awosika is neither in his 20s nor skinny, Vidal pointed out. "There is a significant difference between the person described to police and the person standing here today," Vidal said. As for the vehicle, it is not unusual to see Chrysler 100s or cars with New Jersey plates in the area, Vidal said. She also raised the possibility that Awosika will provide a witness to vouch for his presence elsewhere at the time of the alleged robbery, Vidal said. A Springfield native, Awosika has a close family ties, as shown by his mother, brother and fiance coming to Court Monday to support him, Vidal said. Before his arrest Friday, Awosika was employed and was scheduled to start a new job on Monday, the lawyer said. Hadley set bail at $50,000 and revoked the defendant's bail in the 2017 case. The judge also found probable cause that Awosika violated his probation in the 2016 case and ordered him held for a violation hearing. Awosika is due back in Court on April 12 for a pretrial hearing in his latest case.

Houston police investigators talking to witnesses said that they heard shots around 11 pm last night. ... more Image 1 of / 8 Caption Close Houston police investigate separate fatal shootings of cab driver, man in ditch 1 / 8 Back to Gallery Houston homicide detectives have their hands full with two separate investigations in the deaths of two men in unrelated cases early Friday morning. In the most recent case, a cab driver was discovered dead about 7:20 a.m. slumped over in his taxi in a parking area in front of the Camden Vanderbilt apartments at 7300 Brompton near Bellefontaine in southwest Houston, according to the Houston Police Department. Police said he had been shot the night before and investigators are reviewing surveillance video from the apartment complex. The cab driver had dropped off a fare about 11 p.m. at the apartments, said HPD Sgt. W.L. Meeler. A short time later more than one suspect approached him as he sat in his cab. The suspects, Meeler said, appeared to have walked to the cab from the street. The driver and the suspects had a disturbance and the cab driver got out of the car. Then he was shot. He got back into his cab. The suspects left after the gunfire. It's unclear if the suspects took anything from the cab or the driver. A person who said he had seen the cab parked at the complex Thursday night noticed it parked at the same spot Friday morning. He contacted police, who were originally dispatched to the scene about a person down. Initially, it was not known how he died and it was believed he may have died from natural causes. However, Meeler said, when homicide investigators arrived, they realized he had been shot. No gun was found at the scene. Meeler said investigators don't believe the fare the cab driver had taken to the complex was involved in the shooting. Residents in the neighborhood said the shooting was troubling to them. They said the area is usually quiet and seems safe. David Escarzaga said he lives a few doors down from where the shooting happened. He just moved to the neighborhood about five months ago from El Paso and likes the serenity he found in his new community. But with the killing occurring so close to his front door, he said, it makes him realize how dangerous a big city can be. "It's a little worrisome," he said. In the other shooting, a man was found dead about 6 a.m. lying in a ditch at 4006 Phlox near Duane in south Houston. He had been shot. Police said a passerby spotted the man and called 911. Investigators so far have no motive or suspects in the case. Police said the two deaths appear to be unrelated.

A northern New Jersey man had jumped through a glass door to save his family after masked gunmen broke into his home and beat him, his wife and one of his two young children in what police say appears to be a botched drug robbery early Thursday. Checkey Beckford reports (Published Friday, Jan. 24, 2014) A northern New Jersey man jumped through a glass door to save his family after masked gunmen broke into his home and beat him, his wife and one of his two young children in what police say appears to be a targeted drug robbery at the wrong house. The man told NBC 4 New York he was asleep in his house on 19th Street in Union City early Thursday when four men broke in, woke him up and demanded drugs and money. Police say the burglars had probably intended to break into a different home. “They said, 'Give me the money and the drugs,” the man said. “I said 'Listen, you got the wrong house.'" The man was punched, pistol-whipped and beaten with a crowbar in his bed before the suspects tied him up. The even talked about killing him, he said. "They said, 'That guy's too tough, kill him,'" he said. Some of the gunmen took his wife, 8-year-old daughter and 4-year-old son into another room, where they were also attacked, the man said. The man heard his wife's screams as she was punched in the face and his daughter was was hit in the head with a screwdriver. That’s when the man said he tossed himself through the door in an attempt to save his family. He ran to a neighbor’s house and called police. The suspects left before police arrived, making off with about $300 and cell phones. Anyone with information about the attack is asked to call the North Bergen Police Department at (201) 392-2093.

BY ALEXIS RAMOS A Kew Gardens man who accidentally shot his girlfriend more than two years ago and left her with a serious brain injury is now serving prison time. Steven Diaz, 33, was previously convicted of second-degree criminal possession of a weapon, first degree criminal possession of marijuana and tampering with evidence. According to prosecutors, Diaz accidentally discharged a 9mm handgun inside the apartment he shared with his girlfriend on 127th Street early on the morning of Feb. 9, 2014. His girlfriend was struck in the head, and he brought her by private transport to a local hospital for treatment. Diaz’s girlfriend, now 25, suffered permanent brain damage as a result of the shooting and now resides in a nursing home; her injuries left her unable to communicate with anyone. In trying to explain the incident to police, law enforcement agents said, Diaz claimed that he was a drug dealer and that his girlfriend had been shot as three purported masked robbers invaded their home and looked for marijuana. However, he would later admit to the shooting and claimed that he threw the gun into a sewer. A search of the sewer where Diaz said he threw the weapon ended with negative results. Police, however, did recover more than 50 pounds of marijuana inside his apartment. Diaz was initially tried in March of this year, but it ended in a mistrial when a juror became unable to continue while deliberations were underway. A jury convicted Diaz last month of criminal possession of a weapon, criminal possession of marijuana and tampering with physical evidence. “The lengthy prison sentence imposed by the Court punishes the defendant for the crimes that he committed. Justice has been done,” Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown said in a statement.

At about 2:45 AM on Friday, March 23, 2018, officers from District B-2 (Roxbury) were on patrol in the area of Seaver Street and Humboldt Avenue when they observed a vehicle, occupied by two individuals, operating without headlights. The officer on the passenger side noticed that the front seat passenger, later identified as 24-year-old Jaquan D. Sales of Dorchester, was visibly nervous. For their safety, the officer asked if there were any weapons in the vehicle, to which Sales replied no, but quickly reached for a knife that was attached to his pocket. The officer reached in the window and grabbed Sales’ hand and the knife before having him exit the vehicle. The officer conducted a pat frisk of Sales and the immediate area, including a backpack located on the floor of the passenger seat. The officer felt what was immediately recognizable as a firearm. Joshua Brown, 24, was booked into Orleans Justice Center jail Saturday afternoon, after a witness told police the victim was fatally shot during a fight with Brown, according to his warrant. The warrant identified the man fatally shot as Calvin Powell. The Orleans Parish Coroner's office confirmed Powell's identity Wednesday. Powell was 24-years-old. The warrant states the witness and Powell got into a fight before the shooting, which became physical when the witness slapped Powell, who then punched the witness in the face. The witness then called Brown, told him about the fight and asked him to come over, the warrant said. When Brown arrived at the home in the 8800 block of Stroelitz Street, he and Powell began fighting and the argument quickly turned physical. According to the warrant, a third man came into the apartment during the fight and tried to break it up. During the fight, the witness said they heard more than one shot fired before hearing the third man yell out, "you shot me." Brown then carried the third man out of the apartment and drove him to University Medical Center, according to the warrant. At UMC, the man was treated for a gunshot wound to the leg and Brown was treated for injuries he sustained during the fight, the warrant states. Man and woman shot to death in a car in Holy Cross neighborhood ID'd by coroner The 36-year-old woman and a 51-year-old man were shot to death in a black Acura on Street Claude Court Monday evening (March 19). According to the warrant, police got to the home just after 3:30 p.m., and found Powell lying on the living room floor with a woman "by his side." Powell had more than one gunshot wound, the warrant states. EMS tried to treat Powell, but he was pronounced dead at the scene. Brown was booked into Orleans Justice Center jail Saturday afternoon on one count of second-degree murder, according to online Court records. He appeared in Court the same day, where Orleans Parish Magistrate Commissioner Albert Thibodeaux set his bond for $325,000, Court records show. Attorney information was not immediately available. As of Tuesday afternoon, it was not clear if investigators believe Brown is also responsible for the man who was shot in the leg, but his charges indicate Brown is currently only accused in the fatal shooting. NOPD did not immediately respond Tuesday to questions regarding whether investigators believe Powell also fired a weapon during the shooting. MIAMI (CBSMiami) — The Federal Bureau of Investigation is on the look out for a man and a getaway car involved in the robbery of an armored truck in Miami Thursday morning. According to the FBI, it all happened near the Regions Bank located at 6013 NW 7TH Avenue at approximately. 9:20 a.m. The robber, armed with a gun in each hand, approached the armored truck guard and displayed two handguns and took a courier bag containing an undisclosed amount of money, according to the FBI. No shots were fired and no were injuries reported. The FBI believes the getaway vehicle is a late 90’s green four-door Pontiac with tinted windows, possibly a Grand Am or Grand Prix, that was last seen traveling south on NW 6th Court, then east on NW 60th Street away from the robbery location. They believe that the first three digits of the getaway vehicle’s tag are “393.” The robber is described as a Black male, 5’11” to 6’ in height wearing a dark-colored hoodie, dark pants and a cloth bandana covering face. He was the passenger in the getaway vehicle described above. Anyone with information is urged to call the FBI at (305) 944-9101 or Crimestoppers.

A 23-year-old felon was arrested Wednesday after police stopped his vehicle and found a gun hidden in a pizza box, authorities said. Kristopher D. Mayo remained in the Pulaksi County jail Thursday morning on a charge of possession of a firearm by certain persons. Bail had not yet been set. According to a North Little Rock police report, officer stopped Mayo's pickup shortly before 11 p.m. in the 2500 block of Franklin Street because it had objects hanging from the rearview mirror obstructing the driver's view. Police then learned Mayo's license was suspended and that there was a warrant from Pulaski County out for his arrest, the report said. During a subsequent inventory of the truck, officers found a handgun inside a pizza box that was on the seat, police wrote. The report noted Mayo was convicted of a felony in August of 2012. He's due in Court later Thursday morning.

LYNDHURST, Ohio — Police investigating the attack of a Shaker Heights restaurant owner at his home found three guns they believed the group carried during the incident, including an assault rifle, reports say. Reports say two handguns were found at the home in the 1400 block of Edgefield Road where the attack occurred and the assault rifle was found in the backyard of a home in the 1500 block of Brainard Road, about two blocks east. The Cleveland trio was charged Tuesday in Lyndhurst Municpal Court, including one man who is in the midst of a criminal case in which he is accused of selling drugs. Donta Robinson, 31, Omari Westley, 31, and Artemous Roulette, 20, all entered no pleas Tuesday to first-degree felony charges of aggravated robbery at their initial appearance. All three are held in jail without bond and their cases were bound over to a Cuyahoga County grand jury, which will decide how the case will proceed. Robinson, according to Court records, pleaded not guilty in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court to two counts of drug trafficking, two counts of drug possession and possessing criminal tools on Jan. 13, five days before the attack. Someone called 9-1-1 about 3:40 a.m. Saturday. Only screams could be heard in the background. Dispatchers obtained an approximate location of the call and sent officers to the home, where a 2-year-old, a 13-year-old and a 32-year-old woman also live. Reports say the Cleveland trio drove to the home in a white minivan, jumped out and attacked the restaurateur in his driveway. Police said they believe the man may have been targeted by the trio for cash they thought he took home from the restaurant. The man's face was covered in blood when officers arrived. Two men were arrested by police outside the home, including one man who was inside his car. Police found a glove and a handgun near the home. They also reported finding another handgun and a .22-caliber assault rifle magazine in the back yard. Police tracked the other man using a K-9 officer and officers from several different police agencies. Reports say they found the third man in the backyard of a home in the 1500 block of Brainard Road. They also found an assault rifle in the area, along with two gloves. Parma police arrested Robinson Nov. 25 after they pulled over his green 2000 Dodge Caravan on Snow Road and the Queens Highway. Officers noted finding a handgun, a piece of paper with powder on it and a bag with "rock powder" inside the car. Officers noted Robinson never told police he had a CCW permit and referred the case to detectives. Robinson was indicted Dec. 27 and arraigned on Jan. 13. He was released after posting 10 percent of a $10,000 bond.

Friends and neighbors gathered outside a Country Village home yesterday afternoon searching for answers in an apparent murder-suicide that left a Jersey City couple dead. Henry Okongo, 51, and Lydiah Okongo, 40, were found inside 2 Mina Drive suffering from gunshot wounds, the Hudson County Prosecutor Esther Suarez said yesterday. Lydiah Okongo was found on the first floor with multiple gunshot wounds to her head and torso and Henry Okongo was found in the basement with a gunshot wound to the head, Suarez said. They were pronounced dead at the scene around 10 a.m. Two of the couple's children, a 3-year-old boy and a 1-year-old girl, were found inside the home by responding officers, Suarez said, adding that the uninjured boy was taken to Jersey City Medical Center for evaluation. Neighbors, who asked not to be identified, said Lydiah Okongo worked as a nurse and Henry Okongo owned a few laundromats. Public records show Henry Okongo owned a business on Martin Luther King Drive. Hundreds of residents rallied around Henry Okongo to help him save his business in 2013 when his lease was up and he was behind in rent. Henry Okongo is listed as the owner of both 2 Mina Drive -- a corner house -- and 120 Sycamore Road, which stands just behind the other home on the opposite corner. Homicide detectives could be seen sifting through the mail boxes at the Sycamore Road home. Friends say Henry Okongo's brother once lived in the other home but moved to North Carolina. A gun was recovered from the home, sources said, and neighbors say another adult family member lived with the Okongos. The state's Regional Medical Examiner arrived at the scene just before noon yesterday. One body was removed out the front door and the second was brought out from a back door. A white Honda Accord with New York license plates that was parked across the Sreett from the Mina Drive home was towed from the scene and seized by the Hudson County Prosecutor's Office. Neighbors estimate the couple lived in the home for at least a decade. They were described as "lovely people" who were hard working. No one would have expected a tragedy like this to come from that home, residents said. One woman, who asked not to be identified, was nervous as she walked through the neighborhood late yesterday morning. "Oh my god, that's scary," she said as police officers walked out of the home. Yesterday's incident occurred across the Sreett from where Monica Montone was found dead in 2014. The trial of her husband, Kevin, who is accused of the killing, began yesterday morning. Authorities are awaiting results from the Regional Medical Examiner to determine the official cause and manner of death of the Okangos. Anyone with information about the incident is asked to call the Hudson County Prosecutor's Office at 201-915-1345 or leave an anonymous tip on the Hudson County Prosecutor's website. All information will be kept confidential.

The Knox County Sheriff’s Office thinks it knows who’s behind a recent spate of gunshots fired at residences that has left some people rattled in the midcoast. Chief Deputy Timothy K. Carroll said in a statement over the weekend that an investigation has helped authorities identify the individuals involved in the random shots fired at homes in three towns. They had not been charged as of Sunday night. “The individuals involved have been identified by law enforcement and we feel these were isolated incidents and the public should feel safer with the information we have obtained,” Carroll said. “Names will be released at the appropriate time, but until then, trust that we feel confident that no one is in particular further danger related to these complaints.” According to Carroll, shots were fired at homes in Friendship, Cushing and Waldoboro during the early hours of March 15. Investigators from Waldoboro police, the Maine Warden Service, and the sheriff’s office have spent the past several days collecting information and evidence. “The multiple agencies’ investigation obtained crucial evidence and leads as to the identities of the suspects,” Carroll said. Carroll said that firearms and evidence were seized on Friday, but the names of those allegedly involved are being withheld pending review by the Knox County District Attorney’s Office. A 20-year-old Hot Springs man was arrested Monday after authorities found a shotgun in his vehicle at Lake Hamilton High School, according to a police report. Alexander Gilliana is facing a charge of possession of a gun on school property. Officials say deputies responded to the school at 280 Wolf Street in Pearcy about 2:30 p.m. to investigate a report of a driver who was "being very disorderly" after being involved in a Road rage incident earlier that day. According to a probable cause affidavit from the Garland County sheriff's office, Gilliana said he had become involved in a dispute after driving on Airport Road, which began when he pulled out in front of another vehicle and was driving slowly. The other vehicle followed Gilliana when he stopped at a nearby business and the driver threatened to assault him "if he did that again," the affidavit said. Police say Gilliana then followed the vehicle "to let them know they can't talk to him like that" before ending up at the high school. A search of the revealed a shotgun under the backseat as well as two boxes of ammunition and four knives, the affidavit said. A Feb. 25 Court date is scheduled.

INDIANANPOLIS, Ind. (Feb. 8, 2014) — A woman was shot in an attempted home invasion on the east side early Saturday morning. People in the home in the 800 block of Gladstone Avenue say two masked men tried to get in through the front door around 2 a.m. Someone answered a knock at the door and the two men were there and began trying to force their way inside. That’s when all three people fought to get the door closed. Before they managed to get the door shut, the men fired shots into the home. And once the door was shut, they fired several more shots through the door and wall. A 23-year-old woman who had been asleep on the couch through the commotion, was shot in the stomach. She was awake and breathing when medics arrived and rushed her to Eskenazi Hospital, but there is no word on an updated condition. Police are still investigating the attempted break-in and shooting and have not released any suspect descriptions.

PAWTUCKET, R.I. -- A deliveryman for a Chinese restaurant was robbed at gunpoint Wednesday night. PAWTUCKET, R.I. -- A deliveryman for a Chinese restaurant was robbed at gunpoint Wednesday night. The driver for Best Taste, on Mineral Spring Avenue, was trying to deliver to 175 Newell Avenue at 9:20 p.m., when a short young man in a white hooded sweatshirt approached with a gun, said Pawtucket police Maj. Arthur Martins. The gunman took the driver's money and the meals, and fled. The robbery was a set up; police discovered that the Newell Avenue residents hadn't placed an order. Martins said it wasn't clear whether this delivery robbery was related to a spate of similar robberies late last fall.

UAB Highlands shooting: Longtime nursing supervisor killed by disgruntled worker Nancy Swift, a 63-year-old Mississippi native, was described by those who knew her as a sweet, kind soul. Tim Isley, a 28-year-old supervisor in surgical instruments sterilization, was critically wounded. One person was killed and another wounded in a shooting Wednesday evening at UAB Hospital Highlands. A third person -- the gunman -- then shot and killed himself, according to Birmingham police. One victim, an employee, was shot multiple times in the chest and rushed to the main UAB Hospital. The second victim was being treated at Highlands. At least one of the two injured is a male. The surviving victim is in stable condition, police said just before 10 p.m. The shooter, a male, was found dead in a third floor emergency room from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. At 6:55 p.m., police received the citywide call of an active shooter at the hospital. "There is no threat to the public," Lt. Peter Williston said at 8:40 p.m. UAB Highlands shooting: Longtime nursing supervisor killed by disgruntled worker Nancy Swift, a 63-year-old Mississippi native, was described by those who knew her as a sweet, kind soul. Tim Isley, a 28-year-old supervisor in surgical instruments sterilization, was critically wounded. After police determined the scene was secure, officers searched each room. Paramedics entered the building through the same-day surgery entrance and were taken to the second floor where it was believed the victims were located. Employees were led to UAB Police headquarters. One woman who appeared to be an employee collapsed from an apparent panic attack and was examined by medics. After going into a lock-down following reports of the shooting, UAB around 7:45 p.m. sent an alert saying police "issued an all clear." Birmingham Fire and Rescue Service Capt. Harold Watson said the shooting points to the need for more active shooting training for first responders and for the general public to be more aware of their surroundings. View Full Caption DNAinfo/Sonja Sharp CROWN HEIGHTS — A man who pulled a gun on a friend during a fight about money in Crown Heights last week wound up killing his friend's pit bull and shooting himself in the neck by accident, police said. Mark McLeod, 33, was in his unidentified friend's basement on Union Street when the argument broke out about 8 p.m. Jan. 29, police said. McLeod whipped out a silver handgun, leading to a tussle during which the gun went off, according to the Brooklyn District Attorney's criminal complaint. McLeod fired two more shots as his 31-year-old friend fled upstairs, where the friend's three young children were playing, police said. McLeod then blasted another two rounds at the man's pet pit bull when the dog rushed to his master's aid, according to the criminal complaint. The dog died of apparent gunshot wounds, according to the complaint. At some point in the melee, McLeod accidentally shot himself in the neck, police said. He was taken to Kings County Hospital and was later arrested. McLeod was charged with attempted assault, criminal possession of a weapon, child endangerment and animal cruelty, police said. Information about his lawyer was not immediately available. KALAMAZOO, MI - A 33-year-old man is in serious condition after he was shot early Friday, March 16, near Western Michigan University. Kalamazoo police responded at 2:04 a.m. to a report of shots fired in the 700 block of Howard Street. Police found evidence at the scene of firearm being discharged but no victim. Soon, the victim showed at Bronson Methodist Hospital with a gunshot wound. He was driven there by a private vehicle. The victim could not provide police any information about the shooter. Police said he was listed in serious condition. Anyone with information is asked to call Kalamazoo Department of Public Safety at 337-8994 or Silent Observer at 343-2100 or report online at www.kalamazoosilentobserver.com

SAN PABLO — A 55-year-old San Pablo man was fatally shot in front of his 5-year-old son at a gas station Saturday night, police said. Police found Rodrigo Martinez shot several times and slumped in his vehicle at a Shell station in the 2800 block of El Portal Drive about 11:15 p.m., San Pablo police Cmdr. Jeff Palmieri said. Officers discovered his young son in the car with him, physically uninjured but traumatized by the event. “We don’t know if the people who committed this heinous act knew there was a 5-year-old in the car,” Palmieri said. “We’re very happy the child was not hurt, but it is very traumatic with him being 5 years old and not being able to tell us much besides what we already knew.” An ambulance took Martinez to a hospital where he was pronounced dead, Palmieri said. The young boy was turned over to his mother at the scene. Palmieri said that the man and his young son were sitting in a parking space at the time of the shooting, and had not been pumping gas. Investigators did not immediately know why the pair were at the gas station, nor where they were headed. According to Palmieri, Martinez did not have a permanent residence and appeared to be homeless. It was unknown if his young child, who was in his custody at the time of the killing, was also floating from Place to place. No suspects have been identified in the shooting, Palmieri said. Investigators are still searching for a motive, and do not know if the shooting was narcotics-related or perhaps a botched robbery. The homicide was the second in the city in less than a week. Richmond resident Franklin Lopez-Guardado, 19, died in a shooting in the 2100 block of Dover Avenue last Thursday. No arrests have been announced in that case, though two younger males were seen running from the scene, Palmieri said. Palmieri said investigators are looking into whether the two killings may be related. Physical evidence collected from both scenes are being compared to see if anything matches, he said. The slayings were the first in more than a year in the city — San Pablo recorded no homicides in 2013. Authorities asked anyone with information about either killing to contact investigators at 510-215-3150. “The fact that we had two homicides in a week is obviously tragic,” Palmieri said. “I do know for a fact there will be some closure eventually — we’re going to solve this. Between us and the community, that’s what we do.” Contact Rick Hurd at 925-945-4789 and follow him at Twitter.com/3rdERH.

CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Police say a 34-year-old man was shot dead overnight along the 8200 block of Madison Avenue on Cleveland's West Side. Laweldon McDowell was gunned down after a street-side argument about 12:30 a.m. Friday, police said. Officials have named Luis Nitsche, 23, as the suspected gunman. Nitsche, who fled the scene after shooting McDowell once in the chest, is described as 5-feet, 8-inches tall and weighing about 150 pounds. He has brown hair and brown eyes, according to police. Officials did not provide a description of what Nitsche was wearing when he was last seen. Nitsche is also wanted by Cuyahoga Metropolitan Housing Authority Police in connection with an attempted murder that took Place in Decemeber, a spokesman said. McDowell died while being treated at MetroHealth Medical Center, officials said. The Cuyahoga County Medical Examiner's Office will determine the official cause of death. Anyone with information about Nitsche's whereabouts is asked to call the Cleveland Division of Police Homicide Unit at (216) 623-5464.

CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Police in the past week filed murder charges in two separate suspected homicide cases that occurred more than a month apart, according to Court documents. Stephen Ethley of Shaker Heights and Brandon Jones of Wickliffe are each charged with one count of murder - one accused of using his fists, the other a firearm. Police arrested 32-year-old Ethley Friday after they said he repeatedly punched Ricardo Hardy, 35 of South Euclid, in the head, according to Cleveland Municipal Court records. Hardy was taken to the Cleveland Clinic, where he later died from his injuries. The Cuyahoga County Medical Examiner has not yet ruled on the cause of death. Ethley appeared in Cleveland Municipal Court Monday for arraignment, where a judge set his bond at $500,000. His case was boundover to Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court, where he is awaiting indictment. The case against Jones, 34, stems from a Jan. 24 shooting on Westropp Avenue, according to Court documents. Jones and Thomas Hall Jr., of Bedford Heigths, were in the parking lot of an apartment complex about 11:20 p.m. A short time later, Hall was found with a gunshot wound in his stomach. Hall was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center, where he died Feb. 6. The medical examiner has not ruled on Hall’s death, either. Police arrested Jones on Feb. 20, and accused him of pulling the trigger. Jones was also scheduled to appear in Cleveland Municipal Court Monday, but the Court rescheduled his arraignment for March 18.

BOARDMAN — A Cleveland man faces numerous charges after police responded to a call about a fight involving a gun Tuesday night, according to a police report. According to the report, police were dispatched to an address in the 30 block of Wilda Avenue about 7:50 p.m. Police arrived to find an agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives holding a suspect at gunpoint. Police also found a pistol on the hood of a car parked in the driveway, according to the report. Police relieved the ATF agent and took custody of the suspect, identified as Herbert Beard, 22. They reported finding numerous bags of suspected marijuana in his possession and said he appeared to be intoxicated. A woman told police Beard had assaulted her and another woman at her residence, and a neighbor said he witnessed the same thing. The neighbor, a gun owner with a valid permit, drew his pistol on Beard and ordered him to the ground, he told police. The ATF agent then arrived on scene and ordered the neighbor to put his gun down, which he did. Beard faces domestic violence, drug trafficking, assault, and aggravated- menacing charges, according to the report.

The man said Franklin reportedly chased him and fired other shots at close range before fleeing the scene. The man was transported to the hospital in critical condition. Initial reports show that a man was shot in the arm and side. The investigation into the second shooting is still ongoing and no additional details have been released at this time.

Two masked and armed robbers force manager of Fort Lauderdale Best Buy Mobile to open safe and get keys to storage area. (Source: Fort Lauderdale PD) FORT LAUDERDALE (CBSMiami) – A Best Buy Mobile store was targeted by masked, armed robbers who made off with a large haul of electronics in Fort Lauderdale and the crime was caught on surveillance video. According to Fort Lauderdale Police, two masked men entered the Best Buy Mobile store located at 1489 SE 17th Street at 10:57 a.m. on Thursday, February 13th. The masked men, both armed, locked the doors after entering the store. With guns drawn, they forced the manager at gunpoint to the store’s office where he was told to open the safe and retrieve the keys to the storage closets. The manager, who feared for his life, complied with the demands. The robbers took the keys from the manager and filled 2 large duffle bags with numerous electronics. With their duffle bags filled, the two suspects ran out the back door of the business in an unknown direction. The total amount of the loss is unknown at this time. Anyone who may have witnessed this incident or who has information regarding the identities of these armed robbers is encouraged to contact Detective Todd Hill at (954) 828-5567 or Broward County Crime Stoppers at (954) 493-TIPS.

A 17-year-old armed with a knife while trying to break into a shed in East Bakersfield was shot in the leg by the homeowner. At about 2:20 a.m. Thursday, Kern County Sheriff’s Office Deputies were sent to the 1100 block of Webster Street on a report of an unknown disturbance. Deputies said they found an adult male victim detaining a 17-year-old male suspect at gunpoint in the front yard of a residence. The suspect had been shot one time in the leg. The victim put his gun away when deputies approached. The victim said he found the suspect trying to break into a locked shed in his backyard. When the victim confronted the suspect, the suspect attempted to stab the victim with a knife. The victim shot the suspect one time in the leg. The suspect dropped his knife, fell to the ground, and was detained until deputies arrived. The juvenile was transported to Kern Medical for treatment of his injuries and will be booked into the Juvenile Hall for numerous felony charges and a juvenile warrant. Based on the circumstances, investigators determined the victim was defending himself while the suspect tried to attack him with a knife. No criminal charges are being sought against the victim.

After hearing a knock on the front door, the victim's father-in-law opened the door and found two males with firearms. The males entered the home and demanded money. The suspects then entered the room of the victim, 33, by breaking down the door. One of the suspects then held a gun to the victim's head and again demanded money. Both suspects then searched the bedroom and after not finding any money, took off with two televisions and fled the home. Police: Felon caught with gun, pot during traffic stop in Riverside A convicted felon is facing charges after being found with a handgun and over 16 grams of marijuana during a traffic stop Tuesday evening in west suburban Riverside. Javier A. Llanas, 22, of Oswego, was charged with felony counts of unlawful use of a weapon by a felon, unlawful delivery of cannabis and unlawful possession of cannabis, according to Riverside police. He also faces a misdemeanor count of possession of drug paraphernalia and citations for various traffic violations, including driving on a suspended license. At 5:06 p.m., officers saw Llanas driving a 2006 Ford with expired registration south in the 3500 block of Harlem Avenue, police said. After pulling over the Ford, officers took Llanas into custody after learning his license was suspended and he had an active warrant out for his arrest for a weapons offense in Kane County. During a subsequent search, officers found a loaded Springfield XDM 9mm pistol in the driver’s seat, police said. They also found a clear plastic bag with three smaller baggies containing 16 grams of marijuana along with a scale, additional plastic bags and other paraphernalia. In addition, the officers recovered gloves and a black face mask. Officers later learned that Llanas had a prior felony conviction for unlawful use of a weapon and didn’t have a valid FOID or concealed carry card, police said. Llanas is being held without bond at Cook County Jail, according to the Cook County Sheriff’s Office. His next Court date was set for March 12. The Ford Llanas was driving was seized, police said.

TCSO.JPG Investigators with the Tuscaloosa County Metro Homicide Unit have arrested a man they believe is responsible for the Thursday night shooting death of a 40-year-old Tuscaloosa man. (Stephen Dethrage | al.com) LAKE VIEW, Alabama -- The man accused of fatally shooting a 40-year-old Tuscaloosa man on I-20/59 Thursday night may have been racing him minutes before the murder, the commander of the Tuscaloosa Metro Homicide Unit said Friday morning. Sgt. Dale Phillips said witness accounts and physical evidence have led investigators to believe that the two men were racing each other down the southbound lanes of the interstate at high speeds when contact was made between their two vehicles. Phillips said there is no evidence to suggest the contact was intentional, but it was enough to destabilize both vehicles and the men wrecked into each other then into the concrete median dividing the interstate before coming to a stop near Exit 100, just outside of Lake View, Ala. 37-year-old Roderick Dale Washington, Jr. is charged with capital murder for the shooting death of a 40-year-old Tuscaloosa man.Investigators say the two were racing down I-20 at high speeds, collided and wrecked their vehicles before Washington shot the other driver. (Tuscaloosa County Jail) After the accident, the suspect exited his now-totaled Chevrolet Impala and walked over to his victim's wrecked Nissan Altima. Sgt. Phillips says evidence suggests he shot the other driver one time while his victim was still in his vehicle. The wounded man, 40-year-old Frederick Lee Blakely , got out of his car but collapsed on the ground and was found dead on the scene. When Lake View police officers and Tuscaloosa County Sheriff's deputies arrived shortly after, they found 37-year-old Roderick Dale Washington, Jr. , the driver of the wrecked Impala. Washington suffered minor injuries in the crash and was taken to DCH Regional Medical Center in Tuscaloosa for treatment. Since then, Phillips said evidence and witness reports gathered gave investigators reason to charge Washington with capital murder. He was taken in to custody and booked in the Tuscaloosa County Jail, where he will be held without bond. Phillips said there was no indication that the men knew each other before they began racing on the interstate Thursday night. He said it was unlikely that the two had a predetermined start and finish line for their race and the contest of speed was probably a spontaneous one initiated on the road. Phillips said the car accident was the sole result of the high rate of speed and carelessness of the drivers, and the state's recent winter weather woes did not come into play. Washington has three speeding tickets against him on record in the Alabama courts system, the most recent written in 2006. He has also had a pistol he was not licensed to carry seized by the Homewood Police Department in 2009, but his Court records don't show a history of violence in the state. Traffic was stopped on I-20/59's southbound lanes for a few hours after the shooting as investigators combed through evidence on the scene and interviewed witnesses. Vehicles were backed up for miles, and Phillips apologized for that, but said the investigation had to be done on the scene and it had to be done thoroughly.

Jesus Duarte (Photo: CONTRIBUTED PHOTO/OXNARD POLICE DEPARTMENT) A man was sentenced Wednesday to 89 years to life in prison for a 2014 double-shooting in Oxnard that killed one and injured another, prosecutors said. Jesus Samuel Duarte, 38, previously pleaded guilty in January to the charges of murder, attempted murder and special allegations that he personally used a firearm in the Feb. 17, 2014 shooting. He also admitted that the crimes were done for the benefit of a criminal Sreett gang, according to the Ventura County District Attorney's Office. The shooting was reported about 6:30 p.m. and left Joshua Van, 24, of Oxnard, dead from a gunshot wound to the chest in the 2000 block of Mariposa Street, Oxnard police said. Dontre Bryant, who was 18 at the time, was shot in the stomach but survived the incident after undergoing surgery at a Ventura hospital, police said. Related:Second arrest made in 2014 double shooting that left one man dead in Oxnard Related:Oxnard fights gang crime with Sreett cameras Van and Bryant were walking to the Circle K on North Ventura Road with a group of people on the night of the murder to get milk for Bryant's baby, said Senior Deputy District Attorney John Barrick. Joshua Van (Photo: CONTRIBUTED PHOTO) At the store there was a brief verbal argument between the group, Duarte and his alleged accomplice Alejandro Morales, Barrick said. When the group started walking back home the suspects confronted the group as the pair drove by, Barrick said. The prosecutor claimed Duarte got out of the vehicle and started shooting at the group. Part of the argument was caught on surveillance camera and led to the arrests of Duarte and Morales after images of the suspects were released to the public, Barrick said. Morales faces the same charges and is due in Ventura County Superior Court on March 19 for a pre-trial conference. He has pleaded not guilty, records show. An 11-year-old was treated Thursday evening in Lawrence for what’s believed to be an accidental shooting by a sibling with a rifle, authorities said. Douglas County sheriff’s deputies were dispatched shortly after 6:30 p.m. March 8 on a report of a shooting that had occurred in the 600 block of North Street, Sgt. Kristen Channel said in an email response to the Journal-World. The deputies learned of the shooting after the child had been taken to Lawrence Memorial Hospital in a personal vehicle. Deputies determined that the 11-year-old boy had been shot in the ankle with a .22 caliber rifle by his 16-year-old brother outside their residence, Channel said. The injury was not life-threatening, Channel said. Channel said Friday that although the sheriff’s office continues to investigate the incident, it is believed to have been an accidental shooting. She said she could not release additional information at this point.

CRANSTON, R.I. -- The police are searching for a gunman who fired into a house near the Providence city line late Thursday night. A small green station wagon was seen speeding away from 43 Hillwood Street after someone fired four to five times into the house around 11:30 p.m. Police Maj. Robert Ryan said that three shots went through a front window, but the residents weren't hit. The car sped north on Hillwood Street toward Union Avenue in Providence. Police were canvassing the neighborhood and seeking any surveillance video to help identify the suspect. The neighborhood has seen gunfire before. In July 2012, two men shooting at each other across Webster Avenue shot into a passing car, and a child was injured by shattered glass. Four months later, someone shot into a house on Franklin Avenue, missing a family inside.

Two men were arrested after a report of an armed sexual assault led to a SWAT situation in Sarasota on Monday, the Sarasota Police Department said. At approximately 3:50 a.m. Monday, officers responded to the 2000 block of 17th Street after a report of an armed sexual battery. The victim told police she had gone to a restaurant with Francisco Serrano, 28, and Pastor Mendiola-Martinez, 26, both of Sarasota, because she wanted to borrow money from Serrano. Afterward, Serrano invited her to sleep at his residence because they had been drinking, and there the two men sexually assaulted her, the victim told police. Mendiola-Martinez then left the house. After the assault the victim left the house, and Serrano pointed a shotgun at her, the victim said. She locked herself in her car, and he tapped the window with the weapon, continuing to point it at her until friends the victim had sent text messages to arrived. He then went in the residence, the victims said. Officers worked with SWAT members to make contact with Serrano through phone calls and a bullhorn, and Serrano was arrested without incident. Mendiola-Martinez was arrested at his home. Serrano has been charged with sexual battery, and aggravated assault with a firearm,. Mendiola-Martinez has been charged with sexual battery. Both men are being held at the Sarasota County Jail, according to jail records.

STATEN ISLAND, N.Y. -- Rayshawn Lawrence went into hiding after allegedly shooting and wounding another man early last year in a drug-related beef in New Brighton, said a law enforcement source. In his bid to lay low, Lawrence, 32, abandoned his pit bull "Daisy," the source said. The young female, who the source said is between 1 and 3 years old, did not fare well. Found two and a half months after the Jan. 29, 2014, shooting, Daisy was emaciated, had multiple sores on her body, frostbite on the tips of both ears, a tail wound with the bone exposed, and a broken vertebrae in her back consistent with being thrown or hit, said the source. Just as disturbing, her collar had worn through the pooch's coat, and was embedded in the layers of flesh and tissue of her neck, resulting in a deep, infected wound, the source said. Lawrence, who lives on Jersey Street, has been indicted on felony charges stemming from both cases to include aggravated animal cruelty and attempted murder, said prosecutors. He has denied the allegations. According to the source and Court papers, the chain of events unfolded when Lawrence became embroiled in a drug-related fight outside a bodega at 402 Jersey Street The battle spilled into the store, where Lawrence allegedly shot the victim, said the source. The defendant then went into hiding and abandoned Daisy, who Court papers said, is also called "Mama." Lawrence was ultimately arrested on April 10, said the source. Officers, executing a search warrant, recovered a .45-caliber handgun from the defendant's home, said the source. Authorities found the dog two days later at another location, the source said. A microchip implanted in the dog's skin connected Lawrence as the owner, said the source. Besides aggravated animal cruelty, Lawrence was charged with two other related counts: Overdriving, torturing and injuring animals, and abandonment of animals, according to information from District Attorney Daniel Donovan's office. With respect to the shooting, Lawrence is charged with attempted murder, criminal weapon possession and two counts of assault. He will next return to state Supreme Court, Street George, on Jan. 30. His lawyer could not immediately be reached for comment. Assistant District Attorney Joe Gim is prosecuting the shooting case; Assistant District Attorney Jane Grinberg is prosecuting the animal-cruelty matter.

A teenager was shot while showing his friend a gun Sunday night, police said. It's the third accidental shooting in Tuscaloosa involving teenagers this year. The teen, 14, found a gun earlier in the week and was showing it to a friend, 15, said Tuscaloosa Violent Crimes Unit assistant commander Capt. Kip Hart. The boys were in a bedroom at a home in the 3200 block of 23rd Street around 8 p.m. "The friend was handing the gun back when it discharged striking the victim," Hart said. "There is no indication that the 15-year-old intentionally shot the victim." The teen was treated at DCH Regional Medical Center for a gunshot wound to the shoulder. The handgun has been recovered and the case is being treated as an accidental injury, he said.

At about 10:50 PM on Monday, February 26, 2018, officers from District A-1 (Downtown) were on patrol in the area of Central Street and McKinley Square due to recent drug and firearm related incidents in the area, when officers observed three males walking across Central Street. Officers new one of the males, 24-year-old Dana Michael Loder of Boston, from past arrests and encounters and had recently received information that he may illegally be in possession of a firearm. The officers approached the males, but Loder attempted to quickly walk away, while the other two individuals stayed to speak to officers. The officers caught up to Loder and, given their knowledge of Loder and the area, attempted to conduct a pat frisk for officer safety. Loder resisted the officers by stiffening his arms and attempting to put his phone, which he was holding in his hand, in his jacket pocket. Officers struggled to continue the frisk and finally had to secure Loder in handcuffs. Once secured, the officers frisked the pocket that Loder continually reached for and immediately felt a hard metal object that they believed to be a firearm. Officers recovered a loaded Rohm RG10 .22 caliber firearm from Loder’s upper right jacket pocket. Officers arrested Loder and charged him with Unlawful Possession of a Firearm, Unlawful Possession of Ammunition, and Unlawfully Carrying a Loaded Firearm.

BAY CITY, MI — Two Saginaw men accused of going on a crime spree in Bay City that involved a home invasion, robbery and sexual assault have accepted plea deals. Their two codefendants, though, are still scheduled for trial in the near future. Quay'von R. Brown, 17, on Wednesday, May 21, appeared in Bay County Circuit Court and pleaded no contest to armed robbery and third-degree criminal sexual conduct. In exchange for his pleas, the prosecution agreed to dismiss two counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct and single counts of larceny in a building, first-degree home invasion, felony firearm and assault with a dangerous weapon. A no contest plea is not an admission of guilt but is treated as such for the purposes of sentencing. One of Brown's codefendants, 20-year-old Sammie L. Wright III, followed his friend's lead and on Thursday, May 29, also pleaded no contest to armed robbery in exchange for the dismissal of larceny in a building, first-degree home invasion, felony firearm and assault with a dangerous weapon. Armed robbery is a life offense. In Cobbs hearings for each man, Bay County Chief Circuit Judge Kenneth W. Schmidt indicated their minimum sentence would not exceed 12 years in prison. The pair's codefendants — Nashawn D. Lane, 18, and Antonio D. Griffin, 19 — are scheduled to go to trial on Tuesday, June 3. Schmidt is presiding. Each of them is charged with armed robbery, first-degree home invasion, larceny in a building, assault with a dangerous weapon and felony firearm. Prosecutors contend the quartet on the evening of Jan. 14 broke into the Bay City apartment of Rufus Smith. A woman who was there at the time testified in a February preliminary examination that four to six masked and armed men barged into the residence. She said one of the men, whom she identified as Brown, took her into a bathroom and raped her. The woman said she was at Smith's Place to buy marijuana, but hadn't actually made the purchase when the intruders arrived. Smith testified in the same hearing that the invaders demanded drugs and money, but he managed to break away from them and flee outside. He said he ran to a neighbor's house to call 911 and did not know the woman was still inside. Smith said he later discovered two TVs, two watches, cologne, marijuana, prescription medicine and cash were missing. Prosecutors also allege that three days later, on the evening of Jan. 17, the men accosted Lori Davis as she backed her car out of her Bay City driveway. Davis testified in a March continuation of the preliminary examination that two of the men approached her car and asked for directions, then one pulled a long gun. Davis said she laid on her car horn and the man took off on foot. Police arrested all four men that same night, after officers observed them exiting an area house. Bay City Public Safety Detective Nate Kamp testified in March that in subsequent interviews, each defendant said he was at Smith's home on Jan. 14, and that Brown said he had some sexual contact with a woman there. Schmidt is to sentence Brown at 8:30 a.m. on Monday, July 7, and Wright at 1:30 p.m. on Monday, July 21.

An Orlando man faces several felony charges — including attempted first-degree murder — after deputies say a botched home invasion landed him in the hospital after the victim fought back. On March 6, deputies responded to a home invasion on Cabo San Lucas Drive, near Texas Avenue and Americana Boulevard. The victim told authorities that two men started following him home after he bought a coffee at a nearby convenience store. When the victim reached the door of his apartment, one of the men pulled out a revolver, demanded money, and struck him in the stomach several times with the gun, according to Court documents. The men then asked the victim where he lived and took away his apartment keys. He pleaded with the men to allow him to move his mother — who had suffered from a stroke — from the living room. After the victim moved his mother, one of the suspects shoved the revolver in his ribs, followed the man into his bedroom and asked for guns and money, deputies said. Eventually, the victim shoved the man holding the gun and punched him in the face. While the two were struggling, the second suspect grabbed a stool and broke it over the victim, according to Court documents. Three gunshots were heard during the fight and the suspects fled the apartment with the victim’s cell phone. Responding deputies found a trail of blood in the apartment. No guns, drugs or large amount of cash were found, deputies said. Later in the day, Tierre Charles, 32, showed up at Central Florida Regional Hospital with several women claiming he had been shot in a drive-by shooting. He had a bullet wound in his chest, deputies said. Investigators realized Charles matched the description of the gunman, and the victim and his roommate were able to pick him out of a photo line-up, according to Court documents. He was booked into the Orange County Jail on Tuesday on charges of attempted first-degree murder, home invasion, possession of a firearm by a convicted felon, battery and theft. He’s being held without bond. Charles also faces separate charges in a February home invasion, in which a victim had his skull fractured and was shot in the leg. He faces charges of attempted murder and home invasion robbery with a firearm in that case. Michael Williams can be reached at miwilliams@orlandosentinel.com, 407-420-5022 or @michaeldamianw. A Phenix City man was a passenger in the car with Troy Saunders when gunfire erupted Friday as they attempted to leave the Super 8 Motel at 2935 Warm Springs Road, Columbus police said. Saunders, 39, and the 21-year-old man were in the 2000 Buick when Saunders left the motel around 12:38 a.m. and stopped in the Road in front of 3103 Gentian Blvd., a quarter-mile away. Saunders of Fort Mitchell, Ala., was shot in the neck and pronounced dead inside the car at 1:10 a.m. The passenger in the car wasn't injured but shots were fired at him, police said. On Saturday, police said a search continues for Christopher Wommack, 19. He is being sought on one count each of murder, criminal attempted armed robbery and aggravated assault in the shooting of Saunders and the assault on the other occupant. Police arrested Niesha Janae Jones, 17, and Mayson Gibson, 20, of Columbus on the same charges. They are held in the Muscogee County Jail for a 9 a.m. Monday hearing in Columbus Recorder’s Court. Please enable Javascript to watch this video GRAHAM, N.C. -- A father in Graham says he came home from the grocery store to find two men with a gun in his living room Wednesday morning. "He put the gun in my head," said the father, who wanted to remain anonymous. He says the men threw him to the ground, assaulted him and then threatened to shoot him if he didn't hand over cash and his car keys. "I was really scared, because I don’t know what they were thinking. Maybe he’ll kill me," said the man. He did what they asked, then the men took his XBox and left in a car parked at a nearby vacant house. "I think these people thought he was gone for the day. Then as fate would have it, he showed up at home -- and lucky him," said Cpt. Steve McGilvray, with the Graham Police Department. McGilvray says the father did the right thing. "He complied with what the gentlemen told him to do. With minimal amount of injury, he was able to be a good witness and pass on information that may give us the opportunity to apprehend these people before they commit other crimes," said McGilvray. Until police do, the Graham resident is trying to look on the bright side. "People are willing to kill for a couple dollars and a video game. That’s no good," said the father. He says he's just happy his 7-year-old daughter wasn't with him. Anyone with information about the suspects is asked to contact the Graham Police Department.

Dale Phillips, the commander of the Tuscaloosa County Metro Homicide Unit, announced a second arrest for the January murder of a Tuscaloosa man who was killed while buying drugs in the city's west side. (Stephen Dethrage | al.com) -- Investigators with the Tuscaloosa County Metro Homicide Unit have charged a second man in the slaying of Joshua Gardner, a 24-year-old Tuscaloosa man shot in early January who died weeks after the shooting. Last Thursday, Demetrius Rashad Foster was booked in the county jail and for his connection to the shooting, and Sgt. Dale Phillips, the commander of the homicide unit, announced another arrest in the case this afternoon. 18-year-old Charles Mackennly Nelson Jr. was arrested Wednesday and charged with capital murder for the January slaying of a 24-year-old Tuscaloosa man. He is being held without bond in the county jail. (Tuscaloosa County Jail) 18-year-old Charles Mackennly Nelson Jr. was arrested Wednesday and also charged with capital murder. Both men are being held in the Tuscaloosa County Jail without bond. New details in the case have also emerged thanks to a deposition filed in the Court case against Foster. According to that document, Gardner went to a home on 20th Street in West Tuscaloosa on Jan. 9 with $2,400 in cash to buy more than a pound of marijuana. A witness in the car with Gardner told investigators he went inside to buy the drugs and came out around 10 minutes later, running from two men. The witness said one was carrying a pistol, and the other was armed with what appeared to be a semiautomatic assault rifle. The deposition says Gardner got in the car and began to Drive away when a shot was fired into the vehicle. Gardner said he'd been hit and switched seats with his passenger, who drove the wounded man to DCH Regional Medical Center, where he was treated for a gunshot wound to his chest. Although Gardner was originally expected to survive the shooting, his condition worsened over the next few weeks. . In a press conference Thursday, Sgt. Phillips said the two arrested men were charged with capital murder because Gardner was shot while he was in a vehicle, and his killing may have been a part of a botched attempt to rob him. Both of those factors warrant a capital murder charge. "When you have an event such as this and there's more than one person involved, everyone involved is charged with the same crime, though that doesn't mean down the Road they'll be convicted of the same thing," Phillips said. "Anyone arrested in the case will probably be charged with capital murder." Phillips said the case is on-going and more witnesses have to be interviewed, but he added that his investigators believe they know which of the two men arrested so far pulled the trigger that night in January and ultimately killed Joshua Gardner.

PALM COAST, Fla. - Three men and a juvenile have been arrested in connection with the burglary of a home on Pine Brook Drive in Palm Coast on Sunday afternoon. Devon Burney, 20, of Edgewater, Tammarick Asbell, 20, of Palatka, Tyrell Williams, 19, of Palm Coast, and a 16-year-old Palm Coast juvenile were arrested on charges of armed burglary of a dwelling. The adults were were being held in the Flagler County Detention Facility and the juvenile at the Division of Youth Services facility in Daytona Beach awaiting first appearance Monday. Flagler County deputies said they received a call at 12:47 p.m. from a resident of Pine Brook Drive who reported seeing the four suspects running between houses in the neighborhood. Additional calls were received placing two of them walking in the area and two others going into a home on Pine Bush Lane, deputies said. Deputies said they responded to the area and established a perimeter in the neighborhood. Shortly thereafter, they saw two suspects walking out of a wooded area carrying a backpack. Upon seeing deputies, the two tossed the backpack they had been carrying over a fence, deputies said. The suspects were taken into custody and the backpack was retrieved. Deputies said they responded to the home on Pine Bush Lane where the other two suspects were seen going into. Deputies established a perimeter around the home and gave verbal commands for them to come out of the home. Both exited without incident and were taken into custody. Deputies said they later learned that one of the suspects lived in the home. Deputies said they recovered all of the property stolen from the Pine Brook Drive home. Among the items were a Kel-Tec 9 mm handgun, two tablet computers, an iPad, an Xbox, cash, credit cards and jewelry. Deputies said they recovered two additional firearms from the home on Pine Bush Lane. They said a shotgun and a 9 mm handgun were later located in the attic of the home. One of the weapons recovered was reported stolen from a home on Wellwater Drive in Palm Coast in January 2012, deputies said. They said the investigation is ongoing and additional charges are pending. "All of the witnesses who called us in this case did a terrific job," said Flagler County Sheriff James Manfre. "They each saw something that they felt wasn't right and called and provided us with crucial information that enabled us to take all of the suspects into custody and put them behind bars." GREEN LAKE, Wis. - Officials are investigating damage caused by shots fired at public Road signs, found in two counties over a period of a few weeks. Green Lake and Marquette County sheriff's officials said someone used firearms to intentionally damage Road signs west of Princeton and east of Montello in late February and early to mid-March. The signs were shot with handgun rounds and birdshot from a shotgun, officials said. Over a dozen signs have been damaged amounting to more than $1,000 in damage. Officials are looking for leads and asked anyone with any information regarding the sign vandalism investigation to contact Green Lake County Crime Stoppers at 800-438-8436, text the tip to GETTHEM at 847411, or email getthem@co.green-lake.wi.us. The Green Lake Sheriff's Office said tipsters may be eligible for a reward for information leading to the arrest of suspects.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. (WTNH) -- On Monday, May, 23, 2016, detectives from the New Haven Police Department's Major Crimes Division secured arrest warrants for four people, charged with the 2014 murder and felony murder of Durrell Law. Chief Dean M. Esserman announced that all four men, three juveniles at the time of the crime, and one adult are in custody. On the afternoon of Jan. 20, 2014, Law was shot to death during a robbery near the Fairways Apartments on Eastern Street. Among the arrested was 23-year-old Joel Alexander, of New Haven. Alexander is a convicted felon, who is charged with felony murder, first degree robbery, firearms crimes and conspiracy to commit first-degree robbery. His bond is $2 million. He was taken into custody on May 24. One juvenile, born in 1998, is charged with felony murder, first degree robbery and conspiracy to commit first degree robbery. He was taken into custody on May 24. A second juvenile, born in 1998, is charged with murder, felony murder, first degree robbery, firearms crimes and conspiracy to commit first degree robbery. A man was wounded Thursday night in what was at least the sixth shooting this week in a swath of Long Beach along or near Pacific Coast Highway. This shooting was a few blocks north of PCH near the intersection of 21st Street and Locust Avenue around 11 p.m., police said. Authorities said they don’t have any description of the suspected shooter, who hit the victim in the upper body. A private citizen took the wounded man to a local hospital before officers arrived, Long Beach police spokeswoman Arantxa Chavarria said. Like most of the other shootings this week, police said the incident may be gang related. This week’s spate of violence in Long Beach began Monday afternoon with a string of three back-to-back shootings on or near PCH. Within the span of about an hour and a half, a group of people shot at someone but missed near PCH and Pine Avenue, a man was wounded near PCH and Martin Luther King Jr. Avenue, and a man was shot to death in the 1300 block of Wesley Drive, which is just north of Long Beach City College’s Pacific Coast Campus. On Thursday afternoon, there was more gunfire near where PCH crosses the Los Angeles River, but nobody was hit, according to police. Police also shot and wounded a man when an officer believed someone pointed a gun in his direction during a traffic stop on PCH near Chestnut Avenue on Tuesday night, according to authorities. Police said the officers were in that neighborhood because the department had deployed more patrolmen throughout its west division to try to suppress the gun violence.

Someone in a four-door sedan fired shots at a group of people gathered outside the JJ Peppers Food Store in the 4800 block of North Sheridan Road at about 7:15 p.m., said Officer Michael Sullivan, a police spokesman. A 23-year-old woman was shot in both thighs, a 24-year-old man was shot in the buttocks and another 24-year-old man was shot in the ankle. All three of them were taken to Illinois Masonic Hospital.

LAS VEGAS (AP) — Police say a 19-year-old has been arrested in the death of an acquaintance who police say was with him shooting guns and drinking alcohol this week in a desert area east of Las Vegas. Police say Soto was arrested Tuesday, several hours after the late Monday shooting on federal land off Lake Mead Boulevard near Pabco Road.

Police are searching for Jamie Javone Evans, who is considered armed and dangerous. Erie police have a suspect in a Saturday night shooting on the city's east side that sent a man to the hospital with seven bullet wounds. Police are searching for Jamie Javone Evans, 25, of 609 E. 11th Street He faces charges including attempted homicide, aggravated assault and reckless endangerment. Evans is considered armed and dangerous, police said. A witness has identified Evans as the person who shot a 34-year-old man, whose name has not been released, outside a residence at 1311 Buffalo Road on Saturday at about 10:45 p.m. The victim was shot four times in the left arm, once in the upper abdomen, once in the side and once in the right shoulder. The victim remained in stable condition at UPMC Hamot on Monday. Evans was seen holding a firearm in both hands and shooting toward the victim as the victim exited a residence and walked toward a vehicle parked in the residence's driveway, according to the criminal complaint. The witness said she knew the suspect as "Jamie." The witness also picked Evans' photo out of a group and identified him as the shooter. Evans is described as a light-skinned black male, about 6-foot tall and weighing around 230 pounds. He has tattoos on his hands and was seen wearing a black hooded sweatshirt, black sweatpants, a red or orange undershirt and a black knit cap at the time of the shooting. Erie police detectives also reviewed surveillance video and spoke to the victim on Monday as they continued their investigation. Shell casings were collected from outside of the residence at 1311 Buffalo Road, where investigators believe the man was living, Police Chief Dan Spizarny said. Search warrants were also served at the residence on Sunday. The house, which sits at the corner of Buffalo Road and Elm Street, had security cameras on it and investigators are reviewing surveillance video from them, Spizarny said. Detectives were also checking areas around the house and in the surrounding neighborhood for additional security cameras that might have captured footage of the incident. The victim is the second 34-year-old man to be shot numerous times in Erie so far this year. Detectives said the other man suffered "multiple gunshot wounds" when he was shot while he sat inside a car in the 700 block of Reed Street on the early morning of Jan. 20. The man was treated for his injuries at UPMC Hamot. The investigation into the Jan. 20 shooting continues. No one has been charged in the incident. If anyone sees Evans, they should call 911 immediately, police said. Anyone with information about Evans should call police at 870-1125, or call Detective Matthew Berarducci at 870-1221 or Detective Sean Bogart at 870-1191. Staff writer David Bruce contributed to this story. Tim Hahn can be reached at 870-1731 or by email. Follow him on Twitter at www.twitter.com/ETNhahn.

Annapolis police charged two men — one of them the cousin of the capital city's mayor — with attempted murder in connection with a January shooting and robbery. Police arrested Maurice Hall 26, and Savvas Andre Pantelides, 24, on Thursday. Pantelides is a cousin of Mayor Mike Pantelides, according to Rhonda Wardlaw, the mayor's spokeswoman. Wardlaw said the mayor had no comment on the arrest. Wardlaw also confirmed that acting city attorney Timothy Murnane was at the police station Thursday when Savvas Pantelides was there. "He wasn't representing the city," Wardlaw said. Murnane couldn't be reached Thursday night. On Jan. 20, officers were called to 20 Silopanna Road where they found a Harwood man in the road, suffering gunshot wounds. The man said he was walking on a footbridge when two men came up to him, one pointing a gun and the other holding a knife. As the man fought his attackers, he heard a gunshot and felt pain in his arm. The victim was shot multiple times and was treated at the Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore. Four days later, he was arrested on drug charges. Police did not say how they connected Hall and Pantelides to the shooting. They are each charged with attempted first- and attempted second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, use of a firearm in a violent crime, armed robbery, robbery, reckless endangerment and theft of less than $1,000. Savvas Pantelides was involved in a 2010 negligent manslaughter by vehicle case that stemmed from a fatal crash on Defense Highway in Crofton in 2009, according to Court records and news reports. A 73-year-old man driving an antique car was killed and Pantelides was seriously injured in the crash. Pantelides entered an Alford plea, in which the does not admit guilt, but acknowledges prosecutors have enough evidence to convict him. Pantelides also has convictions on his record for trespassing, assault of a law enforcement officer and making a false statement to an officer, according to online records. Hall and Pantelides are being held without bail at the Jennifer Road Detention Center in Annapolis, police said. Police said that anyone with information about the case may contact Detective Michael Prout at 410-268-9000 or msprout@annapolis.gov. pwood@baltsun.com twitter.com/pwoodreporter

FLINT, MI -- A convicted Flint sex offender is facing federal gun and drug charges after authorities claim he was involved in a shootout in front of his south Flint home. Federal prosecutors filed the criminal complaint Thursday, Jan. 16, in Flint U.S. District Court against the 45-year-old Flint man over claims that he intended to distribute heroin and that he was a felon in possession of a firearm. The man has not yet been arraigned on the charges. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives were investigating the man and obtained a federal warrant Wednesday, Jan. 15, to search his home on the 2000 block of Terrace Drive near Dort Highway, according to an affidavit filed in the case by an ATF agent. However, Flint police were dispatched to the man's home Jan. 15 for a report of shots fired before federal agents could search the house, according to the affidavit. When Flint police arrived on the scene the man allegedly told them that a woman called his house and asked to borrow money. When the woman arrived at the home the man opened the door and three men entered the home. The 45-year-old man allegedly told federal investigators that he and the men exchanged gunfire in and around the home, according to the affidavit. Authorities said it was apparent that multiple rounds were fired inside the residence from more than one caliber of firearm. The house was processed by Flint police evidence technicians and was eventually searched by federal agents, according to the affidavit. Federal investigators allegedly discovered roughly 68 grams of heroin that was broken up and packaged into different sized amounts and a .45-caliber handgun that was reported stolen out of Burton. Court records show that the suspect was convicted in 1990 in Genesee Circuit Court of two counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct and in 2004 in federal Court for being a felon in possession of a firearm. State records show the suspect is required to register as a sex offender for the rest of his life due to the 1990 convictions. Records show he was compliant with the requirements of the registry at the time of the alleged shootout. The suspect was ordered held in custody until a Wednesday, Jan. 22, detention hearing.

SAGINAW, MI — Two men are facing felony charges after police said they fled from a vehicle matching the description of one seen at a Bridgeport Township shooting. James D. Emerson, 18, and Veneson G. Roby, 20, are charged with carrying a concealed weapon and resisting and obstructing a police officer Feb. 4 in Saginaw. Police have said an individual was shot about 2:30 p.m. that day near the intersection of Sheridan and Williamson. The victim was treated and released from a Saginaw hospital, police said. Later that evening, Saginaw police officers attempted a traffic stop on a vehicle in Saginaw that matched a witness description of a vehicle seen leaving the area of the shooting, police have said. The driver did not stop, and the officers began a car chase, police said. The occupants of the vehicle eventually exited it and ran, police said. Officers and Michigan State Police troopers caught the men, identified as Emerson and Roby, and found two handguns along the route where they ran, police said. Saginaw County Chief Assistant Prosecutor Christopher Boyd said detectives are investigating if Emerson and Roby are connected to the shooting, though neither man is charged in connection with that incident. Test results from the state police crime lab regarding the guns are pending. The concealed weapon charge the men face carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison, while the resisting and obstructing charge carries a two-year maximum penalty. In arraigning the men on Monday, Feb. 10, Saginaw County District Judge Terry L. Clark entered not guilty pleas on their behalf and ordered them held on $15,000 bonds. Both men remain jailed. Emerson and Roby are scheduled for a Feb. 21 preliminary hearing before District Judge M. Randall Jurrens. — Andy Hoag covers courts for MLive/The Saginaw News.
